This is a common starting position in the Queen's Gambit Declined, where White has offered to sacrifice a pawn to gain control over the center.

**The Game:**

1.d4 Nf6 (Carlsen starts with the solid move 1...Nf6 to attack White's pawn)
2.c4 c5 (Nakamura plays 2.c4 to challenge Black's central control)
2...e6 (Carlsen supports his d5 square and prepares for potential development)
3.Nc3 dxc4 (Carlsen takes the pawn, inviting White to sacrifice some structure)

White (Hikaru): 4.e3 Be7 (developing his bishop and putting pressure on the pawn)
Black (Magnus): 4...a6 (playing a preventive move against b4 push)
5.Bd3 Nbd7 (development continues; Hikaru eyes e4 expansion)
6.b4 O-O (Magnus develops his king side pieces and protects his position)

7.O-O h6 (Hikaru tries to prevent g5-g4 expansion; this slightly slows down his kingside development)
8.a4 Nh5 (an interesting plan by Carlsen: targeting f4-g5; also preparing...g5 counterplay)
9.Re1 Qe7 (supporting e5 push; controlling center files)
10.Nxd4 exd4 11.Qe2 Rad8 (simplifying to exchange queens and open lines)

12.exd4 Qxe2+ 13.Kxe2 Na6 14.Rab1 f5 (intensifying the conflict; starting an initiative)

15.f4 g6 (Carlsen has launched his full pawn storm against White; also supporting h-file for possible pawn storm)
16.g4 fxg4 (Nakamura's attempt to break through, trading pawns and gaining file for rooks)
17.fxg4 hxg4 (opening lines for Rook-h, getting his dark-squared Bishop involved soon)
18.hxg4 Rxh1 19.Rxh1 Rxh1# {Checkmate!}

Magnus Carlsen plays the Queen's Gambit Declined, one of his favorite openings.
Hikaru responds with the classical line.
He develops his dark-squared bishop early and gets ready to develop other pieces.
Hikaru Nakamura responds with the classical setup.
Hikaru responds with the Bg5 pin on Black's knight.
He declines the gambit pawn to develop his pieces harmoniously.
Hikaru responds with the classical 3...Nf6 move.
He offers a pawn to White in exchange for rapid development.
He develops his knight to f6, attacking the bishop on g5, while preparing to develop other pieces.
He chooses to delay developing his queenside pieces for now.
Hikaru responds with the classical move Bg5.
He aims to create a solid position with counterplay on the queenside.
He aims to equalize with...d5, but also keeps the position closed by playing...e6 instead of...Nf6.
Hikaru responds with the Bg5 variation, aiming to develop his dark-squared bishop quickly.
He aims to challenge white's central pawn storm with a solid pawn structure.
